reviewText: I have this DVD version as well as the original version on laserdisc from 1992.  They are identical except one number from WONDER BAR (1934) was deleted on the DVD.  It is "Goin' to Heaven on a Mule" sung by Al Jolson.  It's done in blackface, of course, with hundreds of extras and dancers in blackface as well.  Jolson even taps in front of a bunch of watermelson slices!  It's a huge production, but the number was undoubtedly deleted from the DVD because of racial stereotype considerations.So for those of you who are purists or "completists" and still have the laserdisc version, keep it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm not crazy about musicals but Busby Berkley was a genius.  This  is a collection of some of his best numbers without having to watch a whole movie. Absolutely amazing.
Title: N/A

reviewText: All the best dance numbers from his WB period, without all the silly, usually not verygood - or well acted plot getting in the way.It's a little long, and a bit repetitive to watch all 135 minutes in one sitting, but the beautyis, there's no need to.A few of the numbers are flatter than others but most of the 21 here are at least stupefyingand surreal, and the very best transcend the cliche's of Hollywood production numbers andshowcase Berkeley's ability to use song, dance and spectacular camera work to create a veryunique, visual way of telling some pretty dark and/or out there (for their time) sexual stories.
summary: Maybe the best way to watch Berkeley's early art

reviewText: Timeless and creative choreography with interesting angles. Some of the music is really catchy too...like "Petting in the Park" which is also Precode as are several others so he had free license opt some degree. Dick Powell seems to have been a favorite with Berkleyand he is good singing and dancing...who would know that as he was later in Westerns I think...or maybe Film Noir.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What a peasure to see this compilation of Busby Berkeley's musical numbers.They are just outstanding and some of them jaw dropping! The wow factor is definitely here with wonderful melodies,dances and costumes.One thing always puzzled me though:What was the deal with Ruby Keeler? I mean sure she  was pretty but her singing was less than adequate and her tap dancing skills paled in comparison to even Shirley Temple!(Ok,i may be exagerating here,but the fact is...she wasn't very good.)But i do see that she really had great chemistry with  both Cagney and Powell.I really liked Joan Blondell , she was ver expressive in her 3 numbers.Dick Powell could certainly belt out a tune and he  always seemed to enjoy himself being surrounded by an army of beautiful women,can't blame him really!My favourite has to be "By a waterfall",no doubt a fore runner to the Esther Williams' extravaganza that were to come from MGM in later years.How'd they do that!!??!!BRILLIANT!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well...this collection was originally on two laser discs...and all theydid was delete "Goin' to Heaven on a Mule" (thank goodness!).  What youhave left are thirteen lavish Busby Berkeley numbers..cutting edge stufffor the 1930's.  Every one of them is delicious and there to be enjoyedwithout the need to deal with those pesky plots. "The Shadow Waltz" would have to by my all time favorite.  All those neon violins and only oneextension cord have I spotted in nearly sixty years.  However...this is a true treasure...and you can put it on and watch your own favorite when you need a 'pick me up".  If you are really hooked...you can also get"The Gang's All Here" and have two great Busby Berkeley numbers IN COLOR.Yes, one of them is "The Lady in the Tutti Fruity Hat" with Carmen Miranda  and a lot of ladies with BIG bananas.  So, there you have it,a way to satisfy your Busby Berkeley cravings quietly, at home, on the sly.  You'll be glad you did.
summary: All the fun without any of those pesky plots....
Title: N/A

reviewText: What a treat for the eyes (and the ears of course) with twenty-one stunning creations from Busby Berkeley lasting 163 minutes (according to the box).  Other reviewers have mentioned that it is a relief to enjoy these musical treats without having to watch them in the context of the complete movie, I agree, this kind of thirties light escapism with contrived plotting and stilted dialog has really dated.It's the visual spectacle that captures the imagination but don't forget the amazing melodies from Harry Warren who wrote all this music, except 'By a waterfall' which was written by Sammy Fain.  These melodies have been American standards for decades.You'll no doubt have your favorites, mine are: 'By a waterfall', where, for almost eleven minutes, Sammy Fain repeats the melody over and over using different orchestration each time; 'Spin a little web of dreams' with Verree Teasdale singing the intro to the number in a rather haughty voice but looking very seductive in a figure hugging Lurex-type gown; 'Dames' with a hundred chorines tap-dancing away; 'Lullaby of Broadway' for completely over-the-top tap-dancing sequence with two hundred dancers.  Pure magic!Incidentally the actual music from these movies is available as a 'best of BB' two-CD box set and 'The Busby Berkeley Book' (1973) by Tony Thomas and Jim Terry is a pictorial record of all his movies.
summary: All singing, all dancing, all everything
Title: N/A

reviewText: Busby Berkeley (1895-1976) was a directing genius.  His innovations - lots of pretty chorus girls, overhead shots, floor shots, and kaleidoscopic patterns, to name a few - were very innovative for their time, and were copied by other movie directors, used in TV variety shows (Jackie Gleason's June Taylor Dancers pioneered the Berkeley style on TV), and even some of today's music videos.This DVD is an excellent sampler of the best Berkeley routines from the Warner Brothers musicals of the 1930s, including Ruby Keeler's tap solo (on top of a car roof, as legend has it) in42nd Street,Footlight Parade, and the jaw-dropping "Lullaby of Broadway" routine fromGold Diggers of 1935, one of the longest tap numbers ever committed to film.  The individual movies are also available on DVD, but if your prime interest is the production numbers, as mine was, this collection is perfect.Busby Berkeley went on to do even more innovative work at MGM, and lived long enough to see his protégé, Ruby Keeler, star in the 1971 revival ofNo, No, Nanette - The New 1925 Musical (1971 Broadway Revival Cast), but did not live to see his masterpiece,42nd Street (1980 Original Broadway Cast), become a very successful 1980 musical, which included many of the songs featured on this DVD.  Ruby Keeler (1910-1993) did attend the opening night of the musical, on her 70th birthday.  The musical was alsosuccessfully revived in 2001, and has become an American classic.  Why Hollywood hasn't jumped at the chance to make a modern movie remake of this great musical is beyond me.  Sure, it would cost big bucks, but there are quite a few singers and dancers who would love to do such a movie - Kristin Chenoweth, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Audra McDonald, Ma, Melinda Sullivan (of "SYTYCD"), Hugh Jackman, and Savion Glover, to name a few - and I'm sure it would be a big box-office hit as a theatrical movie, or get big ratings as a TV-movie.  In addition, the DVD/Blu-ray sales of such a movie would be enormous.  So come on, Hollyweird, get with the program and make a new 42ND STREET movie musical now!
summary: Great collection of Berkeley dance routines
